ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned more tenses in Spanish
I got to continue my learning of the Spanish language and culture in its countries.
My Spanish improved a lot. I also got a lot of new songs from Profe Reymundi's songs at the beginning of class, which were basically the Spanish version of OneRepublic.
I learned more Spanish grammar, vocabulary, and developed a greater understanding of Spanish-speaking cultures
I learned more advanced Spanish grammar and vocabulary. I learned how to communicate more effectively and read a Spanish play.
A greater understanding of elementary Spanish.
I learned how to use the past and present tenses in Spanish while furthering my understanding of present tenses.

Taking Spanish L2 with Professor Reymundi enabled me to further enhance my speaking skill as the class was conducted in Spanish for its entirety. Additionally, this course allowed me to improve my writing skills to a level where I feel confident enough to write texts outside of the class setting.
Grammar and new vocabulary.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There was a lot of work and overall learned a lot. The format of the exams changed each time slightly and was different than the practice leading to some confusion on my part and I thought the course was well designed with the exception of the exams.
Strengths: the class was very open and constructive criticism was welcomed. I wish that there was more randomized student groups so that I could have gotten to know more people in my course.

Strengths: Learning more tenses was really useful. The supersite assignments were honestly really useful. Prof Reymundi was also really good, she almost never used English (maybe 50 words in English the entire semester combined), which was good mostly. 

Weaknesses: Speed. Class moves way too fast, not nearly enough practice with lessons before exams. For example, we literally learned future tense and then had an exam the next class day on four tenses. Not nearly enough conversation in Spanish, and not a lot of the colloquial language. "Eso es yo" (That is me, directly translated) needs to be said as as soy yo (like this am I, directly translated) to say That is me. We don't have the ability to converse in everyday language, which really is problematic. The LinguaMeetings are the only time when we are forced to produce language immediately, but it's 15 minute session that ultimately isn't that productive either. The course itself is also set up really confusingly. The final project really just appeared out of nowhere, for example, and it was hard to follow which assignments were due when. And then the daily thing is really difficult.
The professor was amazing, always supportive, and kept the class interesting. The canvas page could be a but more organized to keep track of everything.
Sometimes there is a lack of instruction and communication about assignments/projects.

I cannot think of a weakness other than it felt like the professor was being forced to teach according to the departments assignment plan. I think it would have been more culturally and academically enriching if this was relaxed. 
Otherwise the course was amazing.
The teaching was excellent and the students were great people. However, we were in a basement with almost zero windows which did not inspire the class at 9am.
Asynchronous activities lack direction
More organization is needed with the assignments. I felt that the end of year project was not talked about at all until the due date.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No, only if they need to take a language for the distributional. I think it is a lot of work and can be tough to learn in it.
Yes, this is a great class to gain new skills and develop your knowledge in a language.
Yes. This is a beautiful language and we are surrounded by it daily.
Absolutely! Youre learning a useful language with an amazing professor!
Yes
Yes. Spanish is a fun language and this professor was incredible.
Yes, you fulfill your language requirement while taking a fun class.
Yes, I felt it was a key stepping stone following L1.
I do recommend in order to receive language credit.
